perturbation.original_text: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site.
perturbation.changed_text: i-on will endeavor to maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with exceptions for maintenance that i-on considers necessary.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'endeavor to maintain' and 'considers necessary' introduce ambiguity and discretion, weakening the obligation to provide continuous service. The original clause mandated continuous operation except for 'reasonable' maintenance, a standard generally understood. This change makes uptime discretionary and subjective.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA)
perturbation.law_explanation: By significantly weakening the guarantee of continuous service through vague language like 'endeavor' and granting itself broad discretion over maintenance ('considers necessary'), i-on is arguably engaging in a deceptive practice if the service uptime is drastically reduced without clear and conspicuous disclosure. FDUTPA prohibits unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce. The changes introduce an ambiguity that could mislead customers regarding the reliability of the service.

perturbation.original_text: physical space for the Hosting Computer at a facility that maintains proper environmental conditions in the area(s) where the Hosting Computer is located and maintains reasonable efforts to prevent unauthorized access to the physical location of the Hosting Computer
perturbation.changed_text: physical space for the Hosting Computer will be provided. Efforts will be made to provide a suitable environment and address unauthorized access.
perturbation.explanation: This modification removes the objective standard of 'proper environmental conditions' and 'reasonable efforts to prevent unauthorized access,' replacing it with vague assurances. The phrasing 'efforts will be made' is not a guarantee and leaves the level of security and environmental control undefined, creating ambiguity.
perturbation.law_explanation: While this agreement predates the Act, it's prudent to consider. The original clause had an element of control for physical access, where the new wording removes this control. The FIPA requires businesses to take reasonable measures to protect sensitive personal information. By reducing the obligation to simply 'efforts will be made,' without defining what constitutes those efforts, i-on potentially fails to meet the 'reasonable measures' standard if a data breach occurs due to inadequate physical security. The lack of specifics makes it difficult to assess compliance.
perturbation.scraped_snippet: Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine April 15, 2025 Search Statutes: 2024 2023 2022 2021 2020 2019 2018 2017 2016 2015 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 Home Senate House Citator Statutes, Constitution, & Laws of Florida Florida Statutes Search Statutes Search Tips Florida Constitution Laws of Florida Legislative & Executive Branch Lobbyists Information Center Joint Legislative Committees & Other Entities Joint Administrative Procedures Committee (JAPC) Joint Committee on Public Counsel Oversight(JCPO) Joint Legislative Auditing Committee (JLAC) Joint Legislative Budget Commission (JLBC) Joint Select Committee on Collective Bargaining (JSCB) Office of Program Policy Analysis & Government Accountability (OPPAGA) Auditor General Commission on Ethics Economic and Demographic Research (EDR) Florida Historic Capitol Historical Committees Florida Legislative Committee on Intergovernmental Relations (LCIR) Joint Legislative Committee on Everglades Oversight (JCEO) Joint Legislative Sunset Committee (JCSC) Florida Government Efficiency Task Force Legislative Employment Legistore Links Select Year: 2024 2023 2022 2021 2020 2019 2018 2017 2016 2015 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 The Florida Statutes The 2024 Florida Statutes (including 2025 Special Session C) Title XXXIII REGULATION OF TRADE, COMMERCE, INVESTMENTS, AND SOLICITATIONS Chapter 501 CONSUMER PROTECTION View Entire Chapter F.S. 501.171 501.171 Security of confidential personal information. — (1) DEFINITIONS. — As used in this section, the term: (a) “Breach of security” or “breach” means unauthorized access of data in electronic form containing personal information. Good faith access of personal information by an employee or agent of the covered entity does not constitute a breach of security, provided that the information is not used for a purpose unrelated to the business or subject to further unauthorized use. (b) “Covered entity” means a sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, trust, estate, cooperative, association, or other commercial entity that acquires, maintains, stores, or uses personal information. For purposes of the notice requirements in subsections (3)-(6), the term includes a governmental entity. (c) “Customer records” means any material, regardless of the physical form, on which personal information is recorded or preserved by any means, including, but not limited to, written or spoken words, graphically depicted, printed, or electromagnetically transmitted that are provided by an individual in this state to a covered entity for the purpose of purchasing or leasing a product or obtaining a service. (d) “Data in electronic form” means any data stored electronically or digitally on any computer system or other database and includes recordable tapes and other mass storage devices. (e) “Department” means the Department of Legal Affairs. (f) “Governmental entity” means any department, division, bureau, commission, regional planning agency, board, district, authority, agency, or other instrumentality of this state that acquires, maintains, stores, or uses data in electronic form containing personal information. (g)1. “Personal information” means either of the following: a. An individual’s first name or first initial and last name in combination with any one or more of the following data elements for that individual: (I) A social security number; (II) A driver license or identifi

perturbation.original_text: The Customer shall comply with applicable laws, standards, policies, and procedures.
perturbation.changed_text: The Customer should generally be mindful of applicable laws, standards, policies, and procedures.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'shall comply' with 'should generally be mindful' drastically weakens the customer's obligation to adhere to legal and regulatory requirements. 'Be mindful' implies awareness rather than strict adherence, and 'generally' creates an exception to the rule. This introduces significant ambiguity regarding the customer's responsibility.
perturbation.law_explanation: The CFAA prohibits unauthorized access to protected computers and data. By weakening the customer's obligation to comply with 'applicable laws,' i-on creates ambiguity about whether it will enforce policies designed to prevent illegal activities under the CFAA. For example, if a customer uses the hosted site to engage in hacking activities, the modified clause weakens i-on's ability to hold the customer accountable, making them potentially liable and non-compliant with expected levels of security under this act.
